Comments_List: Nuno did a great job leading the workshop.

Hearing a wide range of topics discussed during colloquium presentations, and the Q&A sessions afterwards helped in thinking about what questions/issues to anticipate when preparing one's own papers/presentations in future.
I learned how to present original research to a workshop, how to engage scholars and ask informed questions in workshop environments, and gained a better sense of what my colleagues are working on.
It's a good workshop, but as a non-ISS student it felt a bit alien and there didn't appear to be much of an introduction/way in for outsiders.
I greatly enjoyed the cross-curricular makeup of the ISS workshop. The balance of historians and political scientists brought a perspective that I have not seen in the other workshops.
Yes. I often encourage classmates to attend the ISS workshop.
Do it if you have time - a good way of hearing about some current research and hearing feedback on how to structure one's own research/presentations in future.

Yes, the ISS workshop is the only workshop I have encountered in the Political Science department that reaches across departmental lines and deals regularly with the international relations, security studies, and great power politics issues I care most about.
